awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Asymmetry is Destiny: Structure and Fate of Wolf-Rayet Binary Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Supernovae are the most energetic explosions known. The very most energetic supernovae (SNe) are thought to form from the direct collapse of a rapidly rotating star into a black hole. The types of stellar systems which produce these SNe are not well understood. The very hot, massive stars known as Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars are capable of producing features observed in such SNe explosions. However, the role of WR stars in binary star systems in producing supernovae has not been observationally studied in detail. The investigators will use large telescopes to show how the light from such SNe explosions is polarized; this will help determine how the explosion occurred. They will then use computer models to better understand and interpret material flowing out from the supernovae. They will organize a summer camp for middle-school girls of color, following up with mentoring throughout the school year. They will then assess the feasibility of establishing such a program at USNA. 

This project uses the method of spectropolarimetry to observationally determine the morphology of the winds in WR binaries. Spectropolarimetry probes the scattering history of polarized emission lines, revealing their formation and scattering locations within the system. Existing polarimetric observations of the V444 Cyg system, a prototypical WR+O eclipsing binary, suggest that a shock-cone structure exists due to the collision of the two stars' winds. The study will quantify this behavior in similar systems and determine the range of morphological characteristics winds in WR+O display. Monte Carlo modeling will allow the team to interpret the results, predict polarimetric signatures from interacting binary stars, and compare the results to current theories of WR winds and binary evolutions. They propose to continue a successful pilot project using the RRS instrument on the South African Large Telescope to construct well-sampled polarization phase curves for ~15 WR binary systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Massive stars are important contributors to their galactic ecosystems, shaping their environments through strong stellar winds and enriching the local interstellar medium by distributing heavy elements through supernova explosions. But although the process by which a single massive star explodes as a supernova is well understood, the effects of a close binary companion on this process are still the object of intense study. Binary interactions strongly influence the life cycle of a massive star, giving rise to complex configurations of gas and dust surrounding these systems and creating a wide variety of supernovae, including possible gamma-ray bursts. This project measured the polarization of light emitted from 18 massive Wolf-Rayet binary star systems over their entire orbital cycle to obtain a 3-D view of the shapes, composition, and distribution of material in the colliding winds between the stars. The results are helping us investigate how binary interactions create different kinds of supernovae, as well as how these massive stellar systems influence their surroundings through their winds.

Polarization in these systems occurs when light from the stars and hot, shocked material in the wind collision region interacts with ionized gas in the outer winds; measuring its behavior over time gives us clues to the specific shape, composition, and density of the winds. My students and I analyzed the observational polarization data (obtained with the RSS spectropolarimeter on the Southern African Large Telescope) and created 3-D computer models to interpret the measured polarization from the binaries in our sample. Much of this work is still underway due to delays in finalizing the instrumental calibration of the data; I report preliminary results and plans to extend these in the near future.

Some of our key results are as follows:

Recent Ph.D. graduate Andrew Fullard compiled a large sample of polarization results for WR binaries, finding that a significant fraction showed intrinsic polarization and that some also behaved differently in the light from strong emission lines than in the continuum light from the stars. This suggests that their geometries are likely complex, with different shapes seen in different wavelengths.

Fullard went on to create detailed computational simulations of several WR binary systems, using a 3-D numerical polarization and a neural network emulator. He found that polarization observations can reliably reveal information about the masses of the stars in these systems, which is difficult to obtain in other ways. Fullard and I also contributed to another modeling study that found that the polarization of the light from the companion is likely to be greater than that of the light from the WR star in our systems. These simulations lay the groundwork for reliable interpretation of our spectropolarimetric RSS data.

Ph.D. student Rachel Johnson focused on four systems including nitrogen-rich WR stars and obtained X-ray observations to combine with our spectropolarimetric data. WR21 and WR31 vary in both polarization and X-rays. The X-ray variations provide evidence for colliding winds that are off-center due to the systems’ rotation. Both systems also exhibit possible correlations between the X-rays and polarization that we continue to analyze. WR97 shows both X-ray and polarization variations but may not have colliding winds, and WR71 does not emit X-rays and may not be a binary.

Undergraduate students Toni Panzera, Mary Ringgenberg, and Stella Yoos wrote senior thesis papers on several of the binaries in the RSS sample. They found several exciting preliminary results. WR12 shows dramatic differences in the polarization of its emission lines; several show no orbital variation, suggesting that they scatter in an elongated wind that signifies the WR star is rapidly rotating. WR 47 shows a strong shift in the asymmetry of its line profiles across 1/4 of its orbital phase, indicating a possible 90-degree opening angle to its wind collision cone.

Ph.D. student Emma Lieb is investigating carbon-rich WR systems in our sample and their connection to the longer-period objects like WR140 that create dramatic dusty spirals over time. WR113 shows changes in polarization angle over several years that suggest it produces dust sporadically rather than regularly like WR140.

Collaborator Kenneth Nordsieck has finalized the calibrations for the RSS data by modeling the pupil illumination and simulating spectropolarimetric observations of the full Moon. These calibrations will allow more reliable scientific results from this high-precision instrument.

Our group also used this award to fund DU SciTech, a weeklong summer day camp for girls of color in Denver. The campers came primarily from low-income families; they participated at no cost and took home all camp materials including telescopes, tripods, computers and peripherals, and insect-collecting kits. Campers contributed to a study showing that invasive cheatgrass preferentially grows under streetlights, implying that light pollution is linked to ecosystem change. We also used pre- and post-camp surveys to establish that camp participation strengthened the girls’ belief in their ability to do science.
